subject: Re: Llan, Loch, Ax and Exam
msgSnippet: Check your language preferences. The layout should be listed with the available keyboard layouts. You ll have to start using the language bar (or its
messageBody:
Check your language preferences. The layout should be listed with the available keyboard layouts. You'll have to start using the language bar (or its counterpart in newer versions of Windows).

Happy Digitizing!

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "cossyrosario" <cossyrosario@...> wrote:
>
> I tried running the .exe file, but nothing happened. When I tried
> Start>All Programs to see whether the program had been installed, I
> found nothing.
>
> I'm not a computer expert, but usually have no difficulty in installing
> programs, and have had no difficulty with the fonts either. So I don't
> know what the issue is.
>
> Wonder if you can help.
>
>
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "tim_rice09" <tim_rice09@>
> wrote:
> >
> > Strange, I remember seeing those when I still used the substitution
> fonts. If your setup allows it, I personally would recommend using the
> placeholder Unicode fonts for writing in Quickscript. It makes mixing
> Orthodox and QS a lot easier and is really nice if you want to keep your
> digital QS writings around.
> >
> > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "cossyrosario" cossyrosario@
> wrote:
> > >
> > > These are four characters present in the Wikipedia Chart
> > >
> <http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b6/Quickscript_alphabet\
> \
> > > _revised_names.png> which I do not find in the Junior Script font.
> And
> > > apparently not in the King Script font either.
> > >
> > > I also don't find Eat, Age and Ash in the Junior Script font.
> > >
> > > What font, if any, contains them?
> > >
> >
>

Check your language preferences. The layout should be listed with the avail=
able keyboard layouts. You'll have to start using the language bar (or its =
counterpart in newer versions of Windows).

Happy Digitizing!
